en-us.learning_promise:
This unit introduces your students to Physical Science and Earth and Space Science. They'll explore evidence that matter is made of particles too small to see. They'll learn about gravitational forces on Earth, investigate how the number of daylight hours varies during the year, and research ways to use science ideas to protect Earth’s environment. Finally, they'll create a model to show that energy in animals’ food was once energy from the sun. 

Your students will also practice their social and emotional learning, such as self-regulation, persistence, empathy, self-awareness, and mindfulness with the main characters in the lesson stories.  

Before your students begin this unit, we recommend the following to support their building and programming skills and prepare them for the challenges in this unit: 

- Access the LEGO® Education SPIKE™ [App][1] or install it on classroom devices.  
- Complete the Tutorial Activities (under the Start menu item in the LEGO Education SPIKE App). 
- Try one or more of the lessons in the [Quirky Creations](https://education.lego.com/en-us/lessons/spikeessential-quirky-creations) unit.  

In addition, find [professional development](https://pd.legoeducation.com/pages/37/homeroom-premium) support for hands-on learning, programming, and coding. (Create a free LEGO ID if you don’t have one.) 


  [1]: https://education.lego.com/en-us/downloads/spike-app/software

lessons.lesson_description: Maria notices that when she opens the window, her papers blow around the room. How does that happen?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Maria notices that when she opens the window, her papers blow around the room. How does that happen?

text.content:
Maria notices that when she opens the window, her papers blow around the room. 
How does that happen?

What is air? 
How do you know whether it’s just empty space? Give some evidence from everyday life?
Build a fan that can make a breeze to blow over a paper tower.
Program your fan to make a breeze, starting with the speed set to 100%.

text.content: Use your model to try to blow over the paper tower.
Try different positions for the paper tower, like in front of the fan on one side of it, and closer or farther away.

Step 2.
Try different positions for the paper tower, like in front of the fan, on one side of it, and closer or farther away.
Does the position change how well the fan works to blow over the tower?
Use your model to explain how your fan can move air particles.
Use your model to explain how your fan can blow over a paper tower without touching it.
Use cardboard or other materials to design a better fan blade, and then test again to see what happens.
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Matter

lessons.lesson_description: Daniel loves the way birds stay balanced, even when a branch moves. Help him make a model bird that can stay balanced too.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Daniel loves the way birds stay balanced, even when a branch moves. Help him make a model bird that can stay balanced too.

text.content: Daniel loves the way birds stay balanced, even when a branch moves. Help him make a model bird that can stay balanced too.

What happens when you hold an object up in the air and let go?
Why?

What happens when you pull back a swing or pendulum and let go?
Why?

Help Daniel build a balancing bird model. 
Show that the downward force of gravity will keep the bird upright even when tilted.

text.content: Program your model to make different bird sounds when it is tilted to the right or left and when it is upright.
Use your model to explain the direction of the gravitational force on your bird.
Use your model to explain how gravity returns your bird to its original upright position when it is tilted.
Use your model to explain how your program uses sounds to show the bird’s position.
Build a balancing bird model that does not include the Hub but stays upright even when you tilt it.

Show that the downward force of gravity will keep the bird upright even when tilted. 
Explain why.
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Gravity

lessons.lesson_description: Sofie wants to light the path near her campsite for safety. Help her set an overhead lamp to be on at night when it’s dark.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Sofie wants to light the path near her campsite for safety. Help her set an overhead lamp to be on at night when it’s dark .

text.content: Sofie wants to light the path near her campsite for safety. Help her set a lamp to be on at night when it’s dark.
About when was sunrise and sunset yesterday?
About how many hours of daylight do we have this month?
In what seasons is daytime the shortest and the longest?

Build a lamp to illuminate the path by Sofie’s campsite at night when it’s dark. 
Decide how long it should be lit.
Graph the average hours of daylight each month for a full year and then identify the average number of hours it is dark during your assigned month.

text.content: Program your lamp to light the path for the average number of nighttime (darkness) hours in your assigned month.
Use your model and graph(s) to explain how the length of daylight and the time the sun rises and sets change throughout the year.
Use your model and graph(s) to explain what patterns you notice.
How long is nighttime (darkness) during your assigned month?
Add a path and trees to expand Sofie’s campsite.
Then test the model and program to make sure the lamp illuminates the path at night when it’s dark.
Change the model and program to improve the lamp and test again.
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Daytime and Nighttime

lessons.lesson_description: Leo takes good care of Spike Town. How can you care for the environment in your community?
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Leo takes good care of Spike Town. How can you care for the environment in your community?

text.content:
Leo takes good care of Spike Town. 
How can you care for the environment in your community?
What are some actions that people take that harm Earth’s environment?
What are some ways that people use science to care for the environment in their communities?
Choose one to investigate.
Research your chosen way using at least two sources.
Begin to build a model that explains your community action.
Use the base model in the picture for ideas if you like.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Essential Protect Environment

text.content: Start to program your model of a community action.
The sample program works for the recycling model.
Use your progress model to explain how it will show your community action.
Keep building and programming your model of a community action.
Use it to share what you learned about the community action.
Great job!

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Protect the Environment

lessons.lesson_description: Daniel, Maria, Leo, and Sofie know that plants use sunlight to grow bigger. Do animals also need it to grow bigger? Build a model to show the team the relationship between sunlight and animal growth.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Daniel, Maria, Leo, and Sofie know that plants use sunlight to grow bigger. Do animals also need it to grow bigger? Build a model to show the team the relationship between sunlight and animal growth.

text.content:
Daniel, Maria, Leo, and Sofie know that plants use sunlight to grow bigger. 
Do animals also need it to grow bigger?
Where do plants get the energy they need to grow?

Where do animals get the energy that they need? 
What do animals use that energy for?
Build and program a model to help the team learn about the sun’s light and animal growth.

- Show the flow of energy from the sun. 
- Demonstrate how animals get and use it.
Share your progress model and explain where energy is present.
Share your progress model and explain how energy flows from the sun to plants and animals.
Share your progress model and explain ways that animals get and use that energy.
Use your completed model to explain where the energy in animals’ food comes from.
Use your completed model to explain if animals need sunlight to grow bigger.
Great job!

(one for every two students)
- LEGO® Education SPIKE™ Essential Set
- Device with the LEGO Education SPIKE App installed

lessons.title: SPIKE Essential Energy Flow

en-us.title: SPIKE Essential Science We Cannot See
en-us.unit_plan_description: Maria, Sofie, Leo, and Daniel want to understand some science ideas that they cannot see. Can you help them?
